Top Level API¶

Graph Create API¶

graph_to_dgl¶

graph2tensor.interface.graph_to_dgl(graph: graph2tensor.client.numpy_graph.NumpyGraph) → dgl.heterograph.DGLHeteroGraph¶

Transfer a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object into a heterogeneous & directed DGLGraph. All the nodes & edges attributes will be put into nodes & edges data, the node label (if had) will also be put into nodes data with key “label”, and the edge probabilities (if had) into edges data with key “edge_probs”.

Parameters

graph – a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object

Returns

a DGLGraph object

graph_from_dgl¶

graph2tensor.interface.graph_from_dgl(dgl_graph: dgl.heterograph.DGLHeteroGraph) → graph2tensor.client.numpy_graph.NumpyGraph¶

Transfer a DGLGraph object into graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph. All the nodes & edges data will be put into nodes & edges attributes, except for node data “label” and edge data “edge_probs”, which will be taken as node label and edge probabilities respectively.

Parameters

dgl_graph – a DGLGraph object

Returns

a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object

graph_from_pg¶

graph2tensor.interface.graph_from_pg(graph_name: str, nodes_def: Dict[str, Any], edges_def: Dict[str, Any], db_host: str, db_port: int, db_database: str, db_user: str, db_password: Optional[str], **kwargs) → graph2tensor.client.numpy_graph.NumpyGraph¶

Build graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph from Postgres or Greenplum.

Parameters

  • graph_name – database schema, it suppose that each graph has it own schema.

  • nodes_def – nodes definitions, see example below for more details

  • edges_def – edges definitions, see example below for more details

  • db_host – host of database

  • db_port – port of database

  • db_database – name of database instance

  • db_user – user of database

  • db_password – password of database

Returns

a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object

Example

>>> nodes_def = {
...     "nodeA": {
...         "attrs": [("attr1", "int"), ("attr2", "float"), ("attr3", "str")],
...         "labeled": True,
...         "node_label": "label"
...     },
...     "nodeB": {
...         "attrs": [("attr1", "int"), ("attr2", "float"), ("attr3", "str")],
...         "labeled": False
...     }
... }
>>> edges_def = {
...     "edgeA": {
...         "src_type": "nodeA",
...         "dst_type": "nodeA",
...         "directed": True,
...         "attrs": [("attr1", "int"), ("attr2", "float"), ("attr3", "str")],
...         "edge_probs": "prob_column"
...     },
...     "edgeB": {
...         "src_type": "nodeA",
...         "dst_type": "nodeB",
...         "directed": False,
...         "attrs": [],
...     }
... }
>>> graph_from_pg(
...     graph_name="graph1",
...     nodes_def=nodes_def,
...     edges_def=edges_def,
...     db_host="127.0.0.1",
...     db_port=15432,
...     db_database="gnn_dev",
...     db_user="gpadmin",
...     db_password=None,
...     default_int_attr=0,
...     default_float_attr=0.0,
...     default_str_attr=''
... )

Model Related API¶

build_model¶

graph2tensor.interface.build_model(name: Optional[str], conv_layers_def: Dict[str, Any], attr_reduce_mode: Optional[str], pre_proc_layers_def: Optional[Dict[str, Any]], reduce_layer_def: Optional[Tuple[str, Dict]], out_layers_def: Optional[Dict[str, Any]], concat_hidden: bool) → graph2tensor.model.models.message_passing.MessagePassing¶

Build a graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing model.

Parameters

  • name – name of model

  • conv_layers_def – convolution layers definitions, see example below for more details

  • attr_reduce_mode – how to reduce attributes of nodes/edges, expected ‘concat’, ‘mean’ or ‘sum’

  • pre_proc_layers_def – pre-processing layers definitions, None means no pre-processing layer, see example below for more details

  • reduce_layer_def – reduce layer definition, receive a tuple whose 1st element is the class name of layer and 2nd element is the args for layer in dict format, or None means average reduction, see graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing for more details

  • out_layers_def – out layers definitions, None means no out layers, see example below for more details

  • concat_hidden – whether or not concatenate outputs of convolution layers

Returns

a graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing object

Example

>>> conv_layers_def = [
...     [("GCNConv",
...         {"input_dims":128+32,
...         "units":128,
...         "add_self_loop":True,
...         "activation":'relu',
...         "name": "gcn1"}),
...      ("GCNConv",
...          {"input_dims":128,
...          "units":64,
...          "add_self_loop":True,
...          "activation":'relu',
...          "name": "gcn2"})],
... ]
>>> pre_proc_layers_def = [
...     ("IntegerLookupEncoder", {
...         "name": "year_lookup",
...         "cate_feat_def": [("year", {"vocabulary": [1971, 1986, 1987, 1988]+list(range(1990, 2021))}), ]}
...      ),
...     ('EmbeddingEncoder', {
...         "name": "year_emb",
...         "cate_feat_def": [("year", {"reduction": "mean", "input_dim": 37, "output_dim": 32}), ]}
...      ),
...     ('AttrConcat', {"name": "feat_concat"}),
... ]
>>> reduce_layer_def = None
>>> out_layers_def = [("Dense", {"name": "out1", "units": 40}), ]
>>> build_model(
...     "gcn_model",
...     conv_layers_def,
...     'concat',
...     pre_proc_layers_def,
...     reduce_layer_def,
...     out_layers_def,
...     concat_hidden=False
... )

train¶

graph2tensor.interface.train(model, model_id, graph, dataset_def, train_loop_def, checkpoint_dir, tensorboard_log_dir, model_save_path=None)¶

Train a model.

Parameters

  • model – graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing object, or other equivalent object of subclass of tf.keras.Model

  • model_id – id of model

  • graph – a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object to generate dataset from

  • dataset_def – dataset definition, see example below and graph2tensor.model.data.DataGenerator for more details

  • train_loop_def – train loop definition, see example below for more details

  • checkpoint_dir – directory to save checkpoints files

  • tensorboard_log_dir – directory to save tensorboard summary files

  • model_save_path – model save path

Returns

model_id passed and training history

Example

>>> dataset_def = {
...     "valid_size": .25,
...     "meta_paths": ["(paper)-[cites]-(paper)-[cites]-(paper)", ],
...     "batch_size": 256,
...     "include_edge": False,
...     "shuffle": True,
...     "sampler_process_num": 1,
...     "converter_process_num": 2,
...     "expand_factors": 10,
...     "strategies": "random",
... }
>>> train_loop_def = {
...     "optimizer": ("Adam", {}),
...     "loss": ("SparseCategoricalCrossentropy", {"from_logits": True}),
...     "metrics": [("SparseCategoricalAccuracy", {}), ],
...     "epochs": 1,
...     "checkpoint_save_freq": 1,
...     "tensorboard_update_freq": 1
... }
>>> model_id, history = train(model, "model_12345678", graph,
...     dataset_def, train_loop_def, "models/model_12345678", "tensorboard_log/model_12345678")

evaluate¶

graph2tensor.interface.evaluate(model, graph, dataset_def)¶

Evaluate a model.

Parameters

  • model – graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing object, or other equivalent object of subclass of tf.keras.Model

  • graph – a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object to generate dataset from

  • dataset_def – dataset definition, see example below and graph2tensor.model.data.DataGenerator for more details

Returns

the value of metrics

Example

>>> dataset_def = {
...     "meta_paths": ["(paper)-[cites]-(paper)-[cites]-(paper)", ],
...     "batch_size": 256,
...     "include_edge": False,
...     "sampler_process_num": 1,
...     "converter_process_num": 2,
...     "expand_factors": 10,
...     "strategies": "random",
... }
>>> metrics = evaluate(model, graph, dataset_def)

predict¶

graph2tensor.interface.predict(model, graph, dataset_def)¶

Predict using a model.

Parameters

  • model – graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing object, or other equivalent object of subclass of tf.keras.Model

  • graph – a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object to generate dataset from

  • dataset_def – dataset definition, see example below and graph2tensor.model.data.DataGenerator for more details

Returns

the prediction results

Example

>>> dataset_def = {
...     "meta_paths": ["(paper)-[cites]-(paper)-[cites]-(paper)", ],
...     "batch_size": 256,
...     "include_edge": False,
...     "sampler_process_num": 1,
...     "converter_process_num": 2,
...     "expand_factors": 10,
...     "strategies": "random",
... }
>>> predictions = predict(model, graph, dataset_def)

predict_and_explain¶

graph2tensor.interface.predict_and_explain(model, graph, dataset_def, explainer, target_class, prob_th)¶

Predict using model and explain result using explainer on graph.

Parameters

  • model – graph2tensor.model.models.MessagePassing object, or other equivalent object of subclass of tf.keras.Model

  • graph – a graph2tensor.client.NumpyGraph object to generate dataset from

  • dataset_def – dataset definition, see example below and graph2tensor.model.data.DataGenerator for more details

  • explainer – explainer used to explain results

  • target_class – index of target class in predictions to explain

  • prob_th – the threshold of probability, only node with probability of target_class greater than prob_th would be explained

Returns

the prediction results and its explanations

Example

>>> dataset_def = {
...     "meta_paths": ["(paper)-[cites]-(paper)-[cites]-(paper)", ],
...     "batch_size": 256,
...     "include_edge": False,
...     "sampler_process_num": 1,
...     "converter_process_num": 2,
...     "expand_factors": 10,
...     "strategies": "random",
... }
>>> for explanations in predict_and_explain(model, graph, dataset_def, explainer, 0, .9):
...
